title: 114_s1760
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Gun Trafficking and Crime Prevention Act of 2015". It addresses firearms trafficking. The "Hadiya Pendleton and Nyasia Pryear-Yard Gun Trafficking and Crime Prevention Act of 2015" amends Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on trafficking in firearms. It prohibits the shipping, transporting, transferring, or disposing of 2 or more firearms to a person if the transferor knows it would violate any law punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. It also prohibits receiving 2 or more firearms if the recipient knows it would violate the law. The provision prohibits making false statements related to the purchase of 2 or more firearms from a licensed dealer if the person knows it is false and would violate the law. The provision prohibits making false statements related to the purchase of firearms from a licensed dealer, with penalties including fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, and additional sentencing for organizers of such violations. The term 'actual buyer' is defined as the individual for whom a firearm is being purchased. The provision prohibits false statements in firearm purchases from licensed dealers, with penalties up to 20 years imprisonment. The term 'actual buyer' refers to the individual acquiring the firearm. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of trafficking in firearms under section 932 of title 18, United States Code. This review includes assessing the penalty structure based on the number of firearms involved to align with Congress's intent. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of trafficking in firearms under section 932 of title 18, United States Code, to increase penalties for those involved in gang-related activities or organized crime.
